hypotheses: Lower average yearly temperatures are associated with higher COVID-19 infection rates (cases per million).
Higher economic openness (trade to GDP ratio) is associated with higher COVID-19 infection rates (cases per million).
Higher democracy index scores are associated with higher COVID-19 infection rates (cases per million).
claim.hypotheses_location: Stated in the Introduction and the Methodology sections where regression models and explanatory variables are specified (paper sections describing model specification and objectives).
claim.statement: Countries with lower average yearly temperatures, greater economic openness, and higher democracy scores report higher numbers of confirmed COVID-19 cases per million people.
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Introduction (opening sections describing the study's aims and main findings).

data.source: Coronavirus infection data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC); average yearly temperature and precipitation from meteoblue.com and indexmundi.com; economic openness (trade to GDP) from the World Bank; democracy index from the Economist Intelligence Unit.
data.wave_or_subset: Cross-sectional snapshot of confirmed COVID-19 cases per million as of April 3, 2020 (data availability up to that date).
data.access_details: Data compiled from public online sources (ECDC, World Bank, meteoblue.com, indexmundi.com, Economist Intelligence Unit); no additional access restrictions stated in the paper.
data.notes: Variables constructed include cases per million (dependent variable). Some explanatory variables (precipitation and population density) were found insignificant and excluded from final models. The paper notes potential underreporting of cases in some countries and cautions about interpreting statistical associations as causal.

method.description: Cross-country regression analysis using Ordinary Least Squares (classical linear regression) to examine associations between COVID-19 cases per million (as of April 3, 2020) and country-level environmental, economic, and social variables. Models include a baseline OLS with explanatory variables (average temperature, precipitation, economic openness, democracy index, population density) and extended specifications incorporating lagged dependent variables. To address multicollinearity with lagged terms, lagged Y was regressed on explanatory variables and the residuals used in the main regression. Diagnostic tests for heteroscedasticity, normality, autocorrelation, and multicollinearity were performed; heteroscedasticity and non-normality were reported.
steps: Collect country-level data on confirmed COVID-19 cases (ECDC) and country characteristics (temperature, precipitation, openness, democracy index, population density) for available countries.
Compute COVID-19 confirmed cases per million population for each country as of April 3, 2020.
Specify baseline OLS regression: Y_i = δ + μ1 X1i + μ2 X2i + μ3 X3i + μ4 X4i + β4 X5i + v_i where Y is cases per million and Xs are explanatory variables.
Estimate alternative models including a lagged dependent variable term Y_i(-j) to capture temporal dependence.
To avoid multicollinearity between lagged Y and explanatory variables, regress lagged Y on explanatory variables and use residuals in the primary regression (two-step residualization approach).
Estimate models using Least Squares (OLS) and assess coefficient significance and model fit across different lag lengths.
Perform diagnostic tests for heteroscedasticity, normality, autocorrelation, and multicollinearity and report findings.
method.models: Classical Linear Regression Model estimated by Ordinary Least Squares (OLS); models including lagged dependent variable (autoregressive term) and a residualization step to mitigate multicollinearity between lagged Y and explanatory variables.
method.outcome_variable: Confirmed COVID-19 cases per million population (cross-sectional value as of April 3, 2020); lagged values of the same variable used in alternative models.
method.independent_variables: Average yearly temperature, average yearly precipitation (initially), economic openness (trade to GDP ratio), democracy index, population density (initially).
method.control_variables: Population density and precipitation were considered but found statistically insignificant and excluded from final reported specifications.
method.tools_software: Excel, STATA, and EViews (software used for data manipulation and estimation).

results.summary: Across estimated cross-country OLS models (sample of 163 countries, data up to April 3, 2020), average yearly temperature is negatively and significantly associated with COVID-19 cases per million, while economic openness and democracy index are positively and significantly associated. Precipitation and population density were found insignificant and excluded from final specifications. Diagnostic tests indicated heteroscedasticity and non-normality in residuals but no severe autocorrelation or multicollinearity. The author cautions that these associations are statistical and do not establish causation.

numerical_results.unit: cases per million per degree (unit implied by model specification)
